message_1:
What is the mass of iron (III) oxide produced when 25 grams of iron reacts with excess oxygen gas according to the following balanced equation?

4 Fe + 3 O₂ → 2 Fe₂O₃
message_2:
To solve this problem, we will use the stoichiometry method. First, we need to find the molar mass of iron (Fe) and iron (III) oxide (Fe₂O₃).

The molar mass of iron (Fe) is approximately 55.85 g/mol.
The molar mass of iron (III) oxide (Fe₂O₃) is approximately (2 × 55.85) + (3 × 16) = 111.7 + 48 = 159.7 g/mol.

Now, we will convert the given mass of iron (25 grams) into moles:

moles of Fe = mass of Fe / molar mass of Fe
moles of Fe = 25 g / 55.85 g/mol ≈ 0.4476 mol

Next, we will use the stoichiometry of the balanced equation to find the moles of Fe₂O₃ produced:

4 Fe → 2 Fe₂O₃

0.4476 mol Fe × (2 mol Fe₂O₃ / 4 mol Fe) = 0.2238 mol Fe₂O₃

Finally, we will convert the moles of Fe₂O₃ into grams:

mass of Fe₂O₃ = moles of Fe₂O₃ × molar mass of Fe₂O₃
mass of Fe₂O₃ = 0.2238 mol × 159.7 g/mol ≈ 35.74 g

So, approximately 35.74 grams of iron (III) oxide (Fe₂O₃) will be produced when 25 grams of iron reacts with excess oxygen gas.
